Title.evidence: Early Active Mobilization vs. Immobilization After Tibialis Posterior Tendon Transfer: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: randomized postoperatively to early mobilization (n=13) or immobilization (n=11). Randomization was achieved using sealed opaque envelopes, with allocation concealed until after surgery. A power analysis determined that a sample size of 10 per group was adequate to detect a 10-day difference in rehabilitation time.

Participants.evidence: 24 patients with irreversible common peroneal nerve paralysis were randomized postoperatively

Intervention.evidence: randomized postoperatively to early mobilization (n=13) or immobilization (n=11)

Objective.evidence: This randomized controlled trial assessed the efficacy of early active mobilization compared to immobilization following tibialis posterior tendon transfer for foot-drop correction in patients with Hansen’s disease.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was rehabilitation time, defined as the duration from surgery to independent walking, with a minimum follow-up of 16 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was achieved using sealed opaque envelopes, with allocation concealed until after surgery.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible for therapists, but outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 24 patients with irreversible common peroneal nerve paralysis were randomized postoperatively

Number_Analysed.evidence: randomized postoperatively to early mobilization (n=13) or immobilization (n=11)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mobilized group experienced a significant reduction in rehabilitation time by an average of 15 days (p<0.001).
